Ask Yourself These 7 Critical Questions FirstYour Frequently-Asked Questions About The Janapar Grant, AnsweredThe UK Cycle Touring Festival Returns For 2016! Get Your Early Bird Ticket NowIntroducing The Janapar Grant, A Travel Grant For Adventurous Young British CyclistsThe Inspirational Story Of Megan And Her Totally Unplanned Central Asian Bike TripWhat are your adventure cycling plans for 2016?For One Week Only, Get The Kindle Edition Of Janapar For Just 99p3 More Big Bike Trips (& 1 Microadventure) You Can Read For Free On This BlogThe EndI don’t want to spend the rest of my life trying to get one over on my younger selfI cycle east out of Aden, savouring every breath of breezeSoon I’d ditched the traditional idea of being lost or found altogetherThis is the very essence of adventure; nothing mighty or medal-winning, simply embracing the unknownMaybe it’s the qat that keeps the peace around hereThen I notice that she is in fact topless, and that my African stereotype has finally been fulfilledAs I roll onto the faint tyre tracks, I know that I am venturing into another stereotypeMaybe I’ll look back at this and think, ‘What an idiot I was back then’Dragons’ teeth of golden stone rose from the Iranian side of the River AraxI couldn’t just quit this life on the road for good, because I’d invested too much in itI would always be alone in this desire to wander in pursuit of something I still didn’t understandI haven’t told anyone the truth about what I’m about to doI’m Tom Allen, and I throw rocks at childrenI realised what an enormous privilege it was to be able to travel with the freedom I’d taken for grantedWe love the idea of being in control of our own personal universe‘YOUYOUYOUYOUYOUYOUYOUYOU!!!!!!’An Affordable & Unique Gift Idea For The Armchair Traveller In Your FamilyAll the plans I’d laid from the comfort of my bedroom seemed so ridiculously irrelevantEach day was filled with acts of heroic defiance and fortitude‘By the way – sorry – what was your name again?’ ‘Tenny. I am Tenny.’The scars on my face were slowly beginning to healWhat happens to me on this journey is mostly outside my controlI had lost my way so badly that I risked losing everythingIt was almost as if the very land conspired to help us on our wayThe route was going to be every bit the challenge we’d imaginedWith a casual gesture along the top edge of a map, Selen sealed the fate of Ride EarthEurope passed into history with the wave of a soldier’s handThe world needs trailblazers. For people to stop treating places and experiences as products to be consumedI would forever relish not knowing what lay round the next bend.This gruff little man seemed to jump at the chance to have three desperate explorers stay the nightI was dimly aware that the proving grounds were coming to an end.‘Velcome to Romania!’If these two jokers could do it, anyone could! Why not give it a go?Why do we value quantifiable achievements over unmeasurable personal growth?What to do with so much time?‘We cycle-travellers are rich beyond measure. Because we have all the time in the world’The ups and downs had depended far more on attitude than altitude‘Cycle on the right, cycle on the right, cycle on the right… or die!!!’‘This’ll be nice for picnics. In the Himalayas.’Norwegians, I’d heard, called this moment ‘the doorstep mile’It was such a delightful little combination of words. It undermined the status quo so wonderfullyI’d never planned on being anywhere near Sudan, alone or otherwiseThe essential beauty of the bicycle journey lies with the freedom that it gifts the riderThe Sahara doesn’t really look like I’d pictured it. But then nowhere ever quite didI went on a journey seeking answers.
